Welcome to the second Student Opportunity Bulletin of the 2023-2024 school year.
This weekly bulletin will inform students, parents, and staff in a timely manner about
internships, academic programs, jobs, community service options, and leadership
initiatives, along with other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please
carefully note deadlines, age requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
These various opportunities utilize different formats. Some are in-person, some
remote, and some will involve a hybrid arrangement. Check each program for their
specific format and schedule. Students should consider applying to any that match
their interests and talents. Some program deadlines are fast approaching – please
do not miss them!
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!
There are a number of excellent new opportunities in this issue with fast-approaching
deadlines - including (just to highlight a few):
EVENTS: The SUBMERGE Marine Science Festival (near Stuy) on Saturday, 9/29;
the “Raising Resilient Girls” free online workshop for parents on 9/25; the Design
Career Fair at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum on 10/3; and the Yale University “Fall
SPLASH” one-day program of on-campus mini-classes in a variety of fields on 11/11
(spots fill up quickly, so check it out soon).
ACADEMICS: The multi-campus STEP STEM free Saturday program for all
students, including Baruch College’s ‘Psychology Research Scholars’ program -
some deadlines are next week!
BUSINESS: The “Rock the Street Wall Street” Business/Personal Finance
program for female students at Stuy (starts 9/26); And Futures & Options offers
outstanding programs for all grade levels, including access to paid opportunities for
juniors & seniors (9/22 deadline).
COMMUNITY SERVICE: The GO Project welcomes student helpers for their in-
tutoring programs.
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT/COLLEGE: There are numerous options, including
the Brooklyn Public Library’s paid StoryTeens internship (for 10th-12th graders);
the ASAP Community Network AAPI project for any students interested in
community issues; And the Let’s Get Ready free SAT Prep program for current 11th
and 12th graders is accepting applications.
MUSEUMS/ART: The Museum of Modern Art’s Teen Film Committee for
students 16 and older begins on 10/1.
PARKS/ENVIRONMENT: TREEAGE is an Environmental Activism project for
interested students; the Climate Museum offers two exciting workshops on the
Environment in October, along with volunteer opportunities for all students; The
B.Q.L.T. non-profit organization welcomes volunteers for their Neighborhood
Community Gardens program (start date approaching).
STEM: The new in-person Perry Initiative Medical Program for female students at
the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan on 12/9 (spots fill up fast!); And the
application deadline & start date for the free Artificial Intelligence virtual course
has been extended to early October.
THEATER/WRITING/FILM: Several different Film Workshops from Reelworks;
the MCC & Irondale Theater programs; the New Group’s MyStory/College Essay
program; the Brooklyn Youth Chorus final auditions on 9/19 and 9/26; And the
Moth Teen Story programs for 10th-12th graders (application deadline: Sunday, 9/17).
